intro: Anemia costata, commonly known as the "striped nettle," is a species of flowering plant native to certain regions of South America. It belongs to the Urticaceae family, which includes many stinging plants. The plant is characterized by its distinctive, elongated leaves with a serrated margin and a pale, almost white, midrib that runs along its length. Anemia costata typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as forest floors or along stream banks. Its flowers are small and clustered, often appearing in green or reddish clusters, and it produces small, round fruits that contain several seeds.
